Dear Sir Rupert, Residency complimentary slip July 5th. No.303/3/49 of 2. I conveyed to Allcard the contents of Cairo te legram No.9. He did not like the reference to limited experience; he said that the man of 51 was too old to bring here for the first time and the one of 22 a little young. 3. I suggested that he should send a telegram to the English Coaling Company telling them of the men Audsley had found and asking them to vet them together with any others they might know of themselves. The reason for this tail piece was that the English Coaling Company being on the Canal is doubtless closer in touch with the supply of diesel engineers than Audsley is. The Manager of the English Coaling Company is also an exceptionally sound man. 4. Allcard agreed to send the telegram but said he was not happy about the Italians. Messrs. Tommina and Uchi and Hussain Yateem had got Italians working for them and he felt that if either of them were to get more or if Italian employees were admitted in respect of other firms the position would amount to discrimination against Gray Mackenzie. 5. I think there is something in this contention. If we decline to let Gray Mackenzie have their two Italians we must, except in most exceptional circumstances, turn down any subsequent applications in respect of Italians. Even if the Shaikh were not to demur it would scarcely be in our interest to have a large Italian colony here (and I understand that there are four or five hundred Italians on the mainland who do not want to go back to Eritrea). The question is: where is the line to be drawn and as this involves a question of policy I should be grateful for your instructions. (303/5/49) PERSIAN GULF RESIDENCY, BAHRAIN. 14th July 1949. -J Your letter No.C/R-286 of the 7th July about the employment of Italians in Bahrain. I note that some Italians are already employed by local firms. I presume that no objection certificates were obtained from the Agency before they were admitted to the island and that some attempt was made to check their antecedents. This may kindly be confirmed. 2 My own view is that there is no objection to our admitting a few high grade Italian arti- sans subject to a check of their antecedents but that we should resist the import of Italian labour 6n a large scale. I should be xnclined therefore to let Gray Mackenzies have their two Italians provided they understand that although we may agree to their employing three or four more as their project develops it is unlikely we shall be willing to go beyond this. —• 1 - Political Resident in the Persian Gulf. mods.abstract: The file contains correspondence relating to the employment of Italians in Bahrain. The file covers two separate cases.The first case concerns the employment of painter and draughtsman, Rino Gardeschi (sometimes spelled Gardeski), in the decoration of the Roman Catholic Church in Manama and more permanently for the construction and maintenance contractors, T Tominna & S Uchi. The correspondence, dating between 28 November 1948 and 3 May 1949, is between Father Barnabas, Catholic Chaplain, Cornelius James Pelly, Political Agent at Bahrain, Charles Dalrymple Belgrave, Advisor to the Government of Bahrain, and T Tominna & S Uchi.The second case concerns the employment of Italian labourers and engineers in the shipping industry, and the shortage of Maltese workers, who are preferred. The correspondence, dating between 4 and 21 July 1949, is between Rupert Hay, the Political Resident at Bahrain, Herbert George Jakins, the acting Political Agent at Bahrain, J E Allcard of Gray, Mackenzie & Company Limited, and J A F Gethin, First Secretary at the Political Residency, Bahrain.Folios 18-19 are internal office notes.
